CHAPTER 10. FATS, OILS AND GREASE
SECTION 14-121. – PURPOSE.
This ordinance is intended to aid in the prevention of sanitary sewer blockages and obstructions caused by the
introduction, discharge and contribution of fats, oils, greases, grease complexes, scum, sludge and other organic polar
compounds into the Town’s wastewater collection system or publicly-owned treatment works by commercial, industrial,
institutional and all other non-residential activities.
SECTION 14-122. – DEFINITIONS.
(1) “Town” shall mean the Town of Red Springs, North Carolina, and its utility service area.
(2) “Person” shall mean any actual person, corporation, partnership, unincorporated association, and any
governmental entity or political subdivision and departments and agencies thereof.
(3) “Grease” “Fats” and “Dark Prints” shall mean all greases, grease complexes, fats, oils, scum, sludges and all
other organic polar compounds derived from animal and/or plant sources that contain multiple carbon
chain triglyceride molecules. Such substances are detectable and measurable using analytical procedures
established in 40 C.F.R. 136. All are sometimes referred to herein as “Grease” or “greases”.
(4) “Wastewater” shall mean any substance introduced, contributed to, or discharged into the Town’s
wastewater collection system or publicly-owned treatment works (“POTW”).
(5) “Grease trap”, “grease interceptor”, or “sand trap” shall mean a device for separating and retaining
waterborne greases and sand complexes before the wastewater which contains such grease exits the
grease trap or interceptor into the Town’s wastewater collection system or POTW. The grease trap or
interceptor also collects settable solids generated by or incidental to commercial, industrial and food
preparation activities.
(6) “Cooking establishment” shall mean any person primarily engaged in the activities of cooking, preparing,
serving or otherwise making available for human consumption any form of foodstuff, and which uses one
or more of the following cooking or preparation methods in connection with such activities: cooking or
preparation by frying (all methods), baking (all methods), grilling, sautéing, rotisserie cooking, broiling (all
methods), boiling, blanching, roasting, toasting, poaching, or any type of cooking or preparation that
produces a hot non-potable product in or on a receptacle that requires washing, rinsing or other form of
cleaning. Such establishments include, but are not limited to, restaurants, cafeterias, extended care
facilities, school cafeterias (public and private), and daycare facilities where meals for more than six (6)
children are prepared, served or otherwise made available for human consumption.
(7) “Non-cooking establishment” shall mean any person primarily engaged in the rendering or preparation of
pre-cooked foodstuffs that do not require or involve any form of cooking. Such establishments include,
but are not limited to, establishments that are primarily engaged in the rendering preparation of cold
dairy and frozen foodstuffs.
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
372
(8) “User” shall mean any person primarily engaged in any commercial, industrial, institutional or other nonresidential
activity who introduces, contributes or discharges (or causes or permits the introduction,
contribution or discharge of) wastewater into the Town’s wastewater collection system or POTW,
including but not limited to any person who introduces, contributes or discharges wastewater into the
wastewater collection system or POTW through any mobile source.
(9) “Commercial establishment” and “industrial establishment” shall mean any user that has the potential to
use, contribute to or otherwise impact the Town’s wastewater collection system or POTW. Such
establishments include, but are not limited to, maintenance facilities, repair facilities and equipment
cleaning facilities.
(10) “Sand Traps” shall mean a design feature in the sanitary sewer line that takes out solids from car washes,
garages, detail shops or any business that washes or cleans vehicles from which the water enters to
sanitary sewer system.
SECTION 14-123. – GREASE TRAP AND INTERCEPTOR INSTALLATION, MAINTENANCE, RECORD KEEPING
AND REMOVAL.
(1) No later than one (1) year after adoption of this ordinance, all users shall install grease traps or
interceptors designed to limit the introduction, contribution and discharge of greases into the Town’s
wastewater collection system or POTW. Grease traps and interceptors with appropriate sampling or
inspection points shall be installed at the user’s expense whenever any user operates a commercial,
industrial, or institutional cooking establishment. Grease traps and interceptors must have a minimum
capacity of one thousand (1,000) gallons or more as required to effect a grease concentration maximum
of 200 mg/l.
(2) Alternative methods of compliance may be approved by the Town if the user demonstrates that
compliance with this ordinance is impossible or impractical at the time of adoption of this ordinance as a
result of limited space. However, any such proposed alternative method of compliance will be required
to meet the performance criteria specified in Section 18-142(1) of this ordinance, and the user must
adequately demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Town that the proposed alternative method will satisfy
those performance criteria. In addition, any such alternative method must be cleaned at a more frequent
interval than is required of grease traps and interceptors under Section 18-142(5) of this ordinance. Prior
to approval of any such proposed alternative method of compliance, documentation of the proposed
method’s actual performance criteria must be submitted to the Town’s Enforcement Official or Public
Utilities Director for review and approval.
(3) Grease traps and interceptors may also be required in other facilities, as deemed necessary by the Town’s
designated Enforcement Official or Public Utilities Director.
(4) Upon the prior written approval of the Public Utilities Director, non-cooking establishments may be
exempted from the requirements of this ordinance after an inspection of the subject premises and
submission of adequate supporting documentation, as deemed necessary in the sole and absolute
discretion of the Public Utilities Director. At a minimum, such supporting documentation shall include:
blueprints of the subject premises, a full and detailed description of the operations and activities at the
subject premises, and a full and detailed list of all potential sources of grease at the subject premises.
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
373
(5) Users shall empty and service grease traps and interceptors to comply with the performance criteria of
this ordinance as often as necessary, but in any event no longer than every sixty (60) days. The Town may
require a specific schedule if deemed necessary by the Public Utilities Director. Under-the-counter types
of grease traps and interceptors shall be cleaned at least daily, and shall comply with the performance
criteria in Section 18-142(1) of this ordinance. There shall be no reintroduction of wastewater back into
the grease trap or interceptor unless and until said wastewater has been proven to contain 200 mg/l or
less of grease. Under no circumstances shall the sludge or scum layer be reintroduced or discharged into
the Town’s wastewater collection system or POTW.
(6) Users shall supply (i) an adequate sampling point downstream of the grease trap or interceptor, prior to
mixing with other sanitary flows, and (ii) an accessible entry into each chamber of the grease trap or
interceptor. The minimum requirement for the sampling point shall be a four inch (4”) vertical clean-out.
The Town shall have the right to inspect at any time and without prior notice.
(7) Users shall retain detailed records on-site for a minimum of three (3) years reflecting all maintenance
carried out pursuant to this ordinance. At a minimum, such records shall contain the following
information: date of service, name of the employee involved, and a receipt reflecting all services rendered
by the waste hauler providing the service.
(8) Users are required to keep the grease trap or interceptor free of inorganic solids such as grit, towels,
gloves, cigarettes, eating utensils, etc., which could clog or settle in the trap or interceptor, thereby
reducing the effective volume or capacity of the trap or interceptor.
(9) Users are required to ensure that all waste material removed from grease traps and interceptors is
disposed of in a manner that complies with all federal, state and local statutes, rules, regulations, policies
and ordinances.
(10) Except as provided herein, for a period of one (1) year following the adoption of this ordinance, no
enforcement actions will be taken under this section for failure to achieve the performance criteria
specified in this ordinance. If, during such period, (i) an obstruction of any of the Town’s sanitary sewer
main(s) occurs and causes a sewer overflow, spill, leak or other event with any environmental impact,
and (ii) such overflow, spill, leak or other event may be attributed in part or in whole to a particular user,
then the Town will seek enforcement action under the Sewer Use Ordinance, and/or the Pretreatment
Enforcement Plan. For purposes of this section, an overflow, spill, leak or other event shall be deemed to
have an environmental impact when (i) such overflow or other event involves an amount of wastewater
equal to or in excess of one thousand (1,000) gallons, or (ii) any amount of wastewater reaches any body
of surface water. Sec. 18-143 Enforcement. The Town shall enforce this ordinance pursuant to the
provisions of Section 18-157 of the Town’s Code of Ordinances and/or the Town’s Pretreatment
Enforcement Plan.

TITLE 15. – PUBLIC WORKS: ELECTRICAL
SERVICES
CHAPTER 1. – GENERAL PROVISIONS
SECTION 15-1. – AUTHORITY OF BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS.
All electric utilities, or portions thereof, owned, leased or operated by the town, whether inside or outside of the
corporate limits, shall be under the full control of the Board of Commissioners, pursuant to authorization in Session
Laws of 1953, chapter 300 and G.S. 160A-311 et seq. The duty of enacting and enforcing rules and regulations governing
the management and control of town properties shall be vested in the Town Board of Commissioners, and the duty of
enforcing such rules and regulations may be delegated.
State Law reference— Authority to operate public enterprises, G.S. 160A-312.
SECTION 15-2. – ESTABLISHMENT OF OFFICE; APPOINTMENT AND REMOVAL.
The Board of Commissioners hereby establishes the office of Electric Utilities Director. The Electric Utilities Director shall
be appointed by the Town Manager and may be removed by the Town Manager as provided by state law.
State law reference— Creation of offices by board, G.S. § 160A-146.
SECTION 15-3. – POWERS AND DUTIES OF THE OFFICE.
The Electric Utilities Director shall be in charge of the electric utility system. He shall be responsible to the town manager
for the proper maintenance, operation and management of such system. He shall perform such duties relative to such
system as may be imposed upon him by this Code or any other ordinances of the town or as may be required of him by
the town manager, under general regulations of the Board of Commissioners.
SECTION 15-4. – CONNECTIONS TO SYSTEM ONLY MADE BY AUTHORIZED PERSONS.
No electrical connection to the town electrical system shall be made by any person other than the Electric Utilities
Director or his representative.
SECTION 15-5. – CONNECTIONS TO SYSTEM ONLY MADE BY AUTHORIZED PERSONS.
It shall be the duty of the persons making connections under the preceding section to return work orders received from
the town Electric Utilities Director indicating the status of such meter readings at the time connections are made.
SECTION 15-6. – VISITING UTILITY STATIONS.
No visitors shall be permitted to enter any electric utility facility unless accompanied by the Electric Utilities Director or
his representative. Under no circumstances shall anyone be allowed to handle or in any way come in contact with any
portion of the equipment contained therein.
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
376
SECTION 15-7. – TAMPERING WITH EQUIPMENT.
(a) It shall be unlawful for any person to tamper with, remove or otherwise interfere with the electric
wires, poles, meters or any other electric equipment, apparatus or materials belonging to the
electric system of the town, with the exception of those licensed electrical contractors so
designated to do so by the town, and then only in the event of necessary repairs or emergency
service to the property of the electric consumers of the town, and with proper notification to the
town by such licensed electrical contractor. It shall be unlawful for any person to remove or damage
property of any kind belonging to the town.
(b) A reward of up to two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) shall be offered to any person furnishing
information leading to the arrest and conviction of any person violating this section.
(c) A fee in an amount as established from time to time shall be charged for the town's cost in
investigating customers who energize their electric service without permission of the town. Service
may be discontinued if this fee is not paid.
(d) For customers who tamper with the electric meters, fees in amount as established from time to
time shall be charged, as itemized as follows, to cover the additional costs to the town. Service may
be discontinued if these fees are not paid:
(1) A fee for verification of the accuracy of the meter after tampering has been established.
(2) A one-hundred-and-fifty-dollar-fee for investigation.
(3) The amount of estimated lost revenue.
(4) Meter repair charges, if the meter is damaged.
(e) Electric utility customers shall protect electric meters and related equipment on their premises from
vandalism or being tampered with in any way, and shall promptly report to the town's electric
department any such vandalism or tampering. If any such vandalism or tampering is not so
reported, the same shall constitute prima facie evidence that such vandalism or tampering was by
the customer.
SECTION 15-8. – ELECTRIC METERS: LOCATION, CONTROL AND ACCESS.
(a) An electric meter shall be placed at such location on a building as the director of electric utilities or his
representative may direct and shall at all times be under the exclusive management and control of the
Electric Utilities Director or his representative.
(b) The director of electric utilities or his representative may enter and have safe access at all reasonable
hours to premises for the purpose of ascertaining the location or condition of wires and meters or
other fixtures attached to town lines.
(c) The director or his representative shall also, at all reasonable hours, have free access to all premises
for the purpose of reading or testing electric meters or examining connections on which town power
is maintained.
(d) Any debris, vegetation, an animal or a locked gate on a fence that may interfere or prevent access to
town equipment, meter, etc. to perform these purposes shall be removed by the customer at the
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
377
request of the town within the time frame given by written notice or the town reserves the right to
disconnect power to the premises until such debris, vegetation, an animal or a locked gate on a fence
is removed to the satisfaction of the director or his representative. An initial 30-day notice, followed
with a ten-day, notice for the customer to correct the problem will be given prior to issuing a ten-day
notice for disconnection. Debris vegetation, an animal or a locked gate on a fence found during an
emergency situation will be removed without notice or compensation to the resident.
(1) Debris is defined as any building material, discarded items, yard waste, etc. that has
been placed near or around an electric meter that hinders access over the normal path
to a meter or the ability of town workers to safely service, repair, inspect or read a
meter.
(2) Vegetation is defined as any shrubs, trees, vines or flowers that are placed around a
meter that hinder access over the normal path to a meter or the ability of town workers
to safely service, repair, inspect or read a meter. Any shrubs or bushes planted near a
meter shall not bear thorns or sharp protrusions. The Town reserves the right to prune,
trim or remove such as necessary to allow access to a meter without any notice or
compensation to the customer if not corrected within the time stated above. A meter
should be completely unobstructed so that it is clearly visible.
(3) Animal is defined as any domestic dog, horse, goat or any other animal that can tied,
chained or fenced and which is capable of inflicting injury to a human. Animals shall be
located inside a building or tied, chained or fenced away form the meter so as not to
hinder access over the normal path to a meter or the ability of town workers to safely
service, repair, inspect or read a meter.
(4) A locked gate on a fence is defined as any lock on a wooden, brick, chain link, etc. fence
that restricts access over the normal path to a meter or the ability of town workers to
safely service, repair, inspect or read a meter.
SECTION 15-9. – REPAIRS.
All repairs or the replacement of electric service meters made necessary by the carelessness, neglect or interference of
customers shall be made by the town at the expense of the customer offending, and the cost thereof shall be collected
as electric light bills are collected.
SECTION 15-10. – CONNECTIONS AND METERS REMAIN PROPERTY OF TOWN.
All electric meters and other equipment furnished and used by the town in installing any electric connection shall be
and remain the property of the town.
SECTION 15-11. – MAINTENANCE OF METERS.
All electric meters shall be kept in good repair and working order by and at the expense of the town.
SECTION 15-12. – RIGHT OF TOWN TO INTERRUPT SERVICE.
The town manager or Electric Utilities Director shall have the right and power at any time, when such action shall be
necessary, to interrupt electrical service: 1) for failure to pay, 2) to prevent damage to any part of the town's electrical
system, 3) to insure the safety of the public or emergency personnel, or 4) to insure the safety of electric utilities
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
378
workers. The town shall not be liable for damages to any person for such interruption nor shall any reduction be made
from the rates established in this article on account of such interruption.
State law reference— Load management of electric power, G.S. § 160A-323.
SECTION 15-13. –REMOVAL OF WIRES, ETC., DURING A FIRE.
During a fire, the Electric Utilities Director or his authorized agent shall have the right and power to cause removal of
any wire and the turning off of all electricity which interferes with the work of the fire department, or such as are liable
to endanger life or property.
SECTION 15-14. –SAME- LIABILITY.
The town shall not be liable for damage to any person for removal of wires or the interruption of electrical service under
the preceding section.
SECTION 15-15. –LIABILITY OF TOWN IN GENERAL.
The town shall not be liable for damages resulting from the use of electricity or the presence of the town's appliances
on the consumer's premises.
SECTION 15-16. –SERVICE POLICIES.
Policies of providing all electric service shall be adopted by the Town Board of Commissioners and shall be made a part
of the minutes in which the action was taken. Certified copies of the official service policies shall be on file with the
Town Clerk and the business office manager, and copies shall be available for the customers of the electric system.
Specific individual variation from adopted service policies may be made only by the Town Manager.
SECTION 15-17. –CONSUMPTION WITHOUT PROPER METERING; UNLAWFUL ACTS.
(a) It shall be unlawful for any person to extend electric wires or electric service of the town in or
outside of any structure or dwelling by attaching thereto additional facility, appliance or
equipment.
(b) It shall be unlawful for any person to connect or arrange any electric wire in such a manner as to
supply electricity to any electrical facility, appliance or equipment where such electricity is used or
can be used without passing through the meter provided or to be provided for registering the
quantity of electricity consumed.
(c) It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to permit the existence or continuance upon any
premises owned, occupied or controlled by him of any connection, arrangement or service of wires
by means of which electricity is used or can be used without passing through the meter provided
for measuring the amount of electricity consumed.
(d) It shall be unlawful for any person to break the seal on any electric meter or to do any other act to
obstruct, alter, injure or prevent the action of a meter used to measure the quantity of electricity
consumed while such meter is in use for such purpose.
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
379
SECTION 15-18. –INSPECTIONS- CONSUMPTION WITHOUT PROPER METERING
(a) The Electrical Inspector of the town is hereby specifically authorized to inspect any premises where it
is known or suspected that electricity is being consumed without being properly metered.
(b) Such inspection may be made during any reasonable hours.
(c) It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse to permit such examination or to obstruct the Electrical
Inspector in the performance of his duty.
(d) In any case in which the Electrical Inspector shall discover that the wires on any premises are so
arranged that electricity is or can be used without being properly metered, the supply of electricity
shall be cut off, and no additional electricity shall be supplied to the premises until an outside meter
has been installed at the expense of the owner of the premises.
SECTION 15-19. –EXTENSIONS TO ELECTRICAL SYSTEM.
Extensions for the purpose of furnishing electric utility service shall be subject to the discretion of the Town Manager in
accordance with the town's established policy covering extension of such service.
SECTION 15-20. – ATTACHMENTS TO ELECTRIC FACILITES.
It shall be unlawful for any person to attach nonutility articles or items to town-owned or town-leased utility structures,
poles, or facilities without prior approval of the Town Manager.
SECTION 15-21. – UNDERGROUND SERVICE.
Any electric utility customer of the town who desires to connect an underground service to the existing overhead
distribution system of the town shall have first, before connecting to the existing distribution system of the town, caused
to be installed a weatherproof fuse disconnecting switch, which switch shall be installed directly below the meter that
will connect to the distribution overhead system. The fuse rating of such disconnecting switch shall be determined by
the electrical utilities director, based upon the size of the entrance and the uses to be made through such underground
service.
SECTIONS 15-22. – 15.25. – RESERVED.
CHAPTER 2. – RATES AND CHARGES
SECTION 15-26. – APPLICATION.
All customers seeking electric service from the Town after the date of adoption of this ordinance shall complete an
application for service. Such application shall be reviewed and amended, as needed, to stay current with existing laws
and policies of the Town and its electrical service department.
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
380
SECTION 15-27. – SERVICE FEES – NEW CUSTOMERS.
(a) New customers to the electric system will be charged a service fee in an amount as established from
time to time and any deposit which is required of all customers.
(b) New residential customer structures connected to the electric system will be charged a service fee
in an amount as established from time to time for the purpose of offsetting the incurred metering
costs of new structures.
(c) New nonresidential customer structures connected to the electric system will be charged a service
fee in an amount as established from time to time for the purpose of offsetting the incurred
metering costs of new structures.
SECTION 15-28. – SERVICE FEES – TRANSFERS.
(a) Customers moving from one location to another within the electric system shall be charged a service
fee in an amount as established from time to time and any deposit which is required of all
customers.
(b) Customers requesting a change in existing service which requires electric utility personnel to
disconnect the electrical service shall be charged a service fee in an amount as established from
time to time.
SECTION 15-29. – DEPOSITS.
(a) Residential.
(1) Any person or entity applying for electric services to be furnished to residential premises shall
make a deposit in accordance with a schedule as adopted from time to time and maintained
in the Town of Washington Fee Manual or, at the town's discretion, in an amount equal to
two-twelfths (2/12;) of the average annual charges based on utility billing history at the
specific location of the service request. Such deposit requirements may be satisfied as
follows:
a. A cash deposit or a billed deposit over a period not to exceed three (3) months,
which deposit shall be refunded by a credit to the customer's account at the end
of the first six (6) month period during which the customer has paid at least six
(6) bills on time and service has not been disconnected for failure to pay and has
not had any returned checks or drafts on the account;
b. Proof that the deposit refund requirements of subsection (a)(1)a. of this section
have been met at another location within the town's system for which the
customer is responsible; or
c. A personal, written guarantee of payment by a current town customer who has
satisfied the deposit refund requirements of subsection (a)(1)a. of this section.
(2) Increases. A deposit may be increased or a new deposit may be required, at the town's
discretion, after the customer fails to pay a bill in a timely manner three (3) times during any
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
381
three (3) year period, has service terminated for nonpayment, or has a check or draft returned
because of insufficient funds or a closed account. The amount of deposit resulting from any
such increase or from the requirement of a new deposit shall be in accordance with the
provisions in this section (a).
(b) Commercial.
(1) Any person or entity applying for electric services to be furnished to commercial premises may
be required to make a deposit in an amount, if any, to be determined based on that person
or entity's credit information along with the history of usage at the service address. Generally,
a deposit shall be in an amount equal to two-twelfths (2/12;) of the estimated annual charges
at the service address. The initial deposit shall be based upon the town's estimate of the
customer's anticipated, annual usage. After six (6) billing periods following the initial deposit,
the customer's actual usage will be reviewed, and the deposit adjusted, to reflect such actual
usage. If the amount of the deposit is decreased, the difference shall be credited to the
customer's account. If the amount of the deposit is increased, the difference shall be billed to
the customer. At any time after the first six (6) billing periods, the town reserves the right to
adjust the then current deposit based upon the customer's actual usage during the preceding
six (6) billing periods. Such deposit requirements may be satisfied as follows:
a. A cash deposit or billed deposit, which deposit shall be refunded by a credit to
the customer's account at the end of the first twenty-six (26) month period during
which the customer has paid at least twenty-four (24) bills on time and service
has not been disconnected for failure to pay and has not had any returned checks
or drafts on the account;
b. Proof that the deposit refund requirements of subsection (b)(1)a. of this section
have been met at another location within the town's system for which the
customer is responsible; or
c. A surety bond or letter of credit that is issued by an entity satisfactory to the
town, is in an amount equal to the amount of the required deposit, and is
irrevocable for a period of at least twenty-four (24) months from the date of the
application.
(2) If the customer chooses to use its credit history at another location(s) to satisfy a deposit
requirement, the customer shall designate such location(s). If service is disconnected at any
such location for nonpayment, the town may disconnect service to any or all such locations
where the customer is served until the customer pays its account(s) in full and otherwise meets
the deposit requirements of this section.
(3) Increases. A deposit may be increased or a new deposit may be required, at the town's
discretion, after the customer fails to pay a bill in a timely manner three (3) times during any
three (3) year period, has service terminated for nonpayment, or has a check or draft returned
because of insufficient funds or a closed account. The amount of deposit resulting from any
such increase or from the requirement of a new deposit shall be established, and be subject to
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
382
later adjustment, in the same manner as an initial deposit is established, and subject to later
adjustment, in accordance with this section (b).
(d) Contractors. Building contractors requesting temporary electric services will not be required to
provide a deposit. However, each building contractor or his representative will be required to make
a written request that includes, among possibly other things, the date, the location of the service
and the name in which the service is requested.
(e) Credit, refund, transfer. When service is disconnected at the customer's request, any deposit on the
account shall be credited to the customer's final bill. If there is any balance remaining in a deposit
after such a credit is administered, the town will hold the final bill and mail it, along with a town
check for such balance, to the customer at the address given by customer. If the disconnected
customer does not provide the town with a valid forwarding address, any such balance will be held
for thirty (30) days at Town Hall before being placed into an inactive status file. Deposit returns
only apply to customers who move off the town's system entirely and not to those customers who
transfer service from one (1) location to another location within the town's system; in which case,
the deposit shall be transferred with the service.
(e) Termination of service. Customers may terminate electric services in person or by phone.
SECTION 15-30. – RATE SCHEDULE.
(a) A schedule of rates for the sale of electricity to all customers shall be adopted by the Town Board
of Commissioners and made a part of the minutes of the meeting in which the action was taken.
Certified copies of the electric rate schedule shall be on file with the Town Clerk and the Electric
Director, and copies shall be available for the customers of the electric system.
(b) The electric rate schedule shall be reviewed and adjusted by the Town Board of Commissioners, as
needed, or upon recommendation of the Town Manager.
SECTION 15-31. – BILLING; PAYMENT; PENALTIES.
(a) All electric meters shall be read on a regular schedule established by the Electric Utility Director and bills
shall be mailed on a cycle basis.
(b) Every bill shall be due when mailed to the customer at the last address provided by the customer. A bill shall
reflect a due date of fifteen (15) days from the billing date shown on the bill. The same notice will serve as a
notice of possible disconnect if payment is not received within thirty-two (32) days of the billing date.
(c) A late payment penalty in the amount of five (5) percent per month shall be imposed upon any outstanding
unpaid balance twenty-five (25) days after the billing date shown on the bill. The late payment penalty will be
reflected on the bill rendered the following month.
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
383
(d) An automated telephone reminder system will attempt to contact all delinquent accounts prior to
disconnection as a courtesy if the customer has provided a phone number.
(e) If payment has not been received within thirty-two (32) days from the original billing date, services will be
disconnected on the thirty-third (33rd) day. After payments in the night deposit are posted and the cutoff
person has left the office for the purpose of disconnecting a delinquent customer, a service fee, in an amount
as established from time to time, will be charged on that date, whether services are disconnected or not.
(f) A customer whose services are disconnected for such delinquency may have services restored during regular
working hours by the payment of the bill in full plus the service fee. If a customer requests that services is
reconnected after regular working hours, their service fee shall be as established from time to time. Payment
must be received by 11:00 a.m., the following day or services will be disconnected.
(g) The customer shall pay all billed utility charges before transferring service from one location to another. The
final bill shall be mailed to the customer's new billing address. If a customer fails to pay his utility bills for any
account where he is listed as the customer and such account becomes delinquent, the town may transfer the
amount owed to any other account where the customer is a primary recipient of utilities and cut off utilities to
such account for nonpayment. The town may also refuse to transfer an account to a new customer's name or
connect services to a new account where the delinquent customer will be a primary recipient of utilities. A
customer is a primary recipient of utilities wherever listed as a customer, resides as a head of household,
resides as a contributor to the household or conducts a trade or business. The town's determination that a
customer is a primary recipient of utilities shall be effective until the customer proves otherwise.
(h) Any customer who has a check or draft returned from any financial institution because of insufficient funds or
a closed account shall be charged a service charge fee in accordance with G.S. 25-3-506.
(i) Customers requesting alternate payment due dates must make such request of the town and utilize the town's
bank draft service. The customer may choose one of the following periods of the month for their bill to be
drafted:
(1) Between the 7th and 16th of the month.
(2) Between the 14th and 24th of the month.
(3) Between the 22nd and 31st of the month.
(4) Between the 28th and 9th of the month.
SECTION 15-32. – TOWN HELD HARMLESS.
It is expressly agreed between the town and users and consumers of electric utilities that no claim for damages shall be
made against the town due to any wire connection or any other equipment malfunctioning or for the accidental failure
to supply electric service.
SECTION 15-33. – METER TESTING; PROTESTING BILLS.
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
384
If an electric customer has an excessive bill and feels that it is caused by a faulty meter, the customer may, by making a
deposit, in an amount as established from time to time with the town, request that the meter be removed and checked.
If the meter is found to be in error, the deposit will be refunded and the bill adjusted for three (3) months. The
adjustment will be based on the percentage of error in the meter.
SECTION 15-34. – ADJUSTMENT OF BILL.
(a) If the town determines that it has overcharged or undercharged a customer on account of its error,
the town shall refund or recover the difference, subject to the following:
(1) The adjustment period shall be limited to the lesser of the actual period during which the
error occurred or twelve (12) months;
(2) The amount of adjustment shall be determined by the electric utility Director based upon
such evidence as deemed appropriate; and,
(3) Any overcharge may be either refunded or credited to the customer and any undercharge
shall be billed to the customer.
(b) If the town determines that it has undercharged a customer on account of any unlawful or
materially misleading act of such customer, the undercharge shall be determined and collected as
set out in subsection (a) of this section, except the adjustment period shall be the actual period
during which the error occurred (up to thirty-six (36) months) or twelve (12) months, if the
adjustment period cannot be determined. The town shall, in addition to collecting such
undercharge, have the right to take such other action against such customer as is permitted by law.
SECTIONS 15-35. – 15.40. – RESERVED.
CHAPTER 3. – POLES AND WIRES
SECTION 15-41. – PERMIT REQUIRED.
No poles for electric, telephone, telegraph or other purposes shall be placed on any street without a permit therefor
being obtained from the town manager upon the approval of the Electric Utilities Director.
State Law reference— Acquisition of right-of-way for poles, etc., G.S. § 62-182; regulation of poles, G.S. § 136-18(10).
SECTION 15-42. – SINGLE LINES OF POLES.
No permit shall be issued for the erection of poles on a street where there is already a line of poles for the purpose of
supporting electric, telephone or communication wires on such street.
SECTION 15-43. – REMOVAL OF DEAD WIRES.
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
385
It shall be unlawful for any electric telephone or communication company to permit any of its disconnected, dead or
unused wires to hang or remain on any pole, structure or house where the same have formerly been connected and in
use.
SECTION 15-44. – CARE AND INSPECTION OF POLES AND WIRES.
It shall be the duty of the owners of all poles supporting electric, telephone or communication wires in the town to keep
such poles in a safe condition by performing routine inspections.
SECTION 15-45. – AGREEMENT TO JINT USE OF POLES.
Whenever any telephone, electric or communication company desires to place wires along any street upon which it
does not have a line of poles, and there are existing poles along such street owned by another company, then such
company shall obtain a Joint Use agreement from the owner of the poles prior to attaching wires upon the poles.
SECTION 15-46. – ARBITRATION.
If an agreement cannot be reached between the company owning the line of poles on any street and another company
desiring to use such poles, then the companies may submit the question of compensation and other pertinent matters
in controversy to three disinterested persons for arbitration, or they may submit the matter to the town board for
determination.
SECTION 15-47. – SAME; APPLICABILITY.
Sections 14-45 and 14-46 shall apply to poles owned by the town as well as to companies operating under franchise
from the town.
SECTIONS 15-48. – 15.55. – RESERVED.
CHAPTER 4. – JOINT MUNICIPAL EASTERN POWER AGENCY/ELECTRICITIES
SECTION 15-56. – GENERAL.
The Board of Commissioners hereby finds that participation in the proposed joint municipal assistance agency will result
in economies, efficiencies and other benefits with respect to the construction, ownership, maintenance, expansion and
operation of the municipality's electric system and that participation in such agency by the municipality as a member is
desirable.
SECTION 15-57. – MEMBERSHIP.
A commissioner and an alternate commissioner from the municipality shall be appointed to the joint municipal
assistance agency, such appointees to serve at the pleasure of the governing board and until their successors are
appointed by the governing body.
SECTION 15-58. – TRANSFER OF INTEREST.
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
386
The municipality does hereby authorize the transfer to the newly formed joint municipal assistance agency of its interest
in such of the assets of ElectriCities of North Carolina, a voluntary association, as may be determined by the board of
directors of ElectriCities of North Carolina.
SECTIONS 15-59. – 15-60. – RESERVED.
CHAPTER 5. – LOAD MANAGEMENT
SECTION 15-61. – DEFINITIONS.
For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them
in this section:
Device: A switch which will temporarily curtail or cut off certain types of appliances or equipment for short periods
of time.
Load management: The utilization of devices to temporarily curtail or cut off certain appliances or equipment for
short periods of time whenever an unusual peak demand threatens to overload the system or economies would result.
Participants: Eligible electric customers of the town who have load management devices installed, maintained,
operated, and placed into service by the town.
SECTION 15-62. – POWERS OF ELECTRIC UTILITIES DIRECTOR- LOAD MANAGEMENT.
The Electric Utilities Director or someone under his control shall have the right and power to temporarily curtail or cut
off certain types of appliances or equipment of participants for short periods of time whenever an unusual peak demand
threatens to overload the electric system or economies would result by putting into service the load management
devices.
SECTION 15-63. – CREDIT FOR PARTICIPANTS.
Participants in the load management program shall receive a credit on their monthly bill based upon the appliances
equipped with the load management device. If a residence is equipped with the device on all the air conditioners or
heat pumps serving the residence, then the per month credit shall be as written in the adopted annual budget ordinance
for the months of June, July, August, and September. If the residence is equipped with the device on all the hot water
heaters serving the residence, then the per month credit shall be as written in the adopted annual budget ordinance.
SECTION 15-64. – ELIGIBILITY.
A residential electrical utility customer of the town shall be eligible to participate in the load management program of
the town if the residence is a single-family dwelling having either a hot water heater with a minimum of 30 gallons with
at least a 4,500 Watt element and not being an instantaneous hot water system, a central air conditioning unit or a heat
pump.
SECTION 15-65. – APPLICATION FOR PARTICIPATION.
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
387
Application for participation in the load management program shall be made on such form as supplied by the town
treasurer. Every person applying to participate shall agree that he will not remove or tamper with any of the load
management devices on his premises, except by a duly authorized agent or representative of the town.
SECTION 15-66. – DEVICE INSTALLATION.
The Electric Utilities Director or someone under his direction shall install the load management devices upon the
appliances of an eligible applicant. No fee shall be charged for the installation of the device unless the participant has
previously had load management devices which have either been tampered with or disconnected, in which case the
actual cost of installation shall be the fee.
SECTION 15-67. – CONTROL OF DEVICES.
The load management device shall at all times be under the exclusive management and control of the Electric Utilities
Director or someone under his direction.
SECTION 15-68. – REPAIR OF DEVICES.
No repair or removal of load management devices shall be made by any other person than the Electric Utilities Director
or someone under his direction. All repairs or the replacement of load management devices made necessary by the
carelessness, neglect or interference of participants shall be made by the town at the expense of the participant
offending, and the cost thereof shall be collected as electric light bills are collected.
SECTION 15-69. – LIABILITY OF TOWN.
The town shall not be liable for damages resulting from the use of load management devices or the presence of the
town's devices on the participant's premises.
SECTIONS 15-70. – 15-80. – RESERVED.
CHAPTER 6. – RENEWABLE ENERGY
SECTION 15.81. – BILATERAL METERING FOR RENEWABLE ENERGY RIDER.
(a) Availability. This rider is available in conjunction with any of the town's electric schedules applicable to
customers who operate an approved renewable energy generating system located and used at the customer's
primary residence or nonresidential facility, where part or all of the electrical requirements of the customer can
be supplied from the customer's generating system.
(b) Rated capacity of the generating system shall not exceed the lesser of the customer's estimated maximum
monthly kilowatt demand or 20 kW for residential systems or 100 kW for nonresidential systems. The generating
system that is connected in parallel operation with service from the town and located on the customer's
premises must be manufactured, installed, and operated in accordance with governmental and industry
standards and in accordance with all requirements of the local code official and must fully conform with the
town's applicable renewable energy generation application and attachments.
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
388
(c) This rider is available on a case-by-case basis, except that the aggregate capacity of the customer generator
shall not exceed five percent of the town's retail peak load for the prior calendar year. If a customer's proposed
installation results in exceeding the limit, the customer will be notified that service under this rider will not be
allowed. In no event will energy delivered to the town be used to offset purchases in a different period or a
different season.
(d) Type of service. This rider is applicable to alternating current 60 hertz, single phase 2 or 3 wires, or three phase
3 or 4 wires, at town's standard voltages.
(e) Additional meter charge. The customer shall pay an additional meter charge of $3.00 per month for meter
reading and account servicing.
(f) Monthly credit. Energy measured as kilowatt-hours at the renewable energy generator meter shall be credited
at the NCEMPA energy wholesale power rate. Sales tax will not be applied to purchased electricity.
(g) Customers with qualified systems are encouraged to also apply for NCGP credits through the NC Green Power
Program (http://www.ncgreenpower.org/).
(h) Power cost adjustment. A wholesale power cost adjustment will apply to all service supplied under this schedule
as necessary to reflect wholesale power increases by the NCEMPA.
(i) Special conditions.
(1) Customer must fill out and submit page one of the application for an approved renewable
energy generating system and pay a $100.00 non-refundable processing fee. Upon receipt,
page two of the application "Certificate of Completion for Renewable Energy Generating
System" form will be completed by the town prior to the customer receiving service under
this rider. Agreement shall include the renewable energy generator interconnection
standards for systems up to 20 kilowatts capacity for residential systems and 100 kilowatts
capacity for nonresidential systems that describes the conditions related to interconnection
with the town's electrical system.
(2) Customer's service installation and transaction shall be a bilateral arrangement with two
standard residential meters, one of which will measure all energy provided by the town for
energy consumed by the customer, and the other meter to measure the output of the
customer's generator.
(3) In the event town determines that it is necessary to install a dedicated transformer or other
equipment to protect the safety and adequacy of electric service provided to other
customers, customer shall pay a monthly facilities charge of two percent of the installed cost
of said additional facilities. The minimum monthly facilities charge shall not be less than
$25.00.
(4) Customer grants town the right to install, operate, and monitor special equipment to measure
customer's load, generating system output, or any part thereof, and to obtain any other data
necessary to determine the operating characteristics and effects of the installation. Customer
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
389
also grants town the right to utilize customer's telephone line to transmit data from town's
meter and special equipment.
(5) The town reserves the right to test the customer's equipment for compliance with the
applicable interconnection standards. Should the town determine that the equipment is in
violation of the interconnection standards, the town shall disconnect the equipment and it
shall remain disconnected until the equipment is repaired to the satisfaction of the authority
responsible for inspection of the installation.
(j) Contract period. Contract period for service under this rider shall be one year and thereafter shall be
renewed for successive one-year periods. After the initial period, customer may terminate service under
this rider by giving at least 60 days' previous notice of such termination in writing to the town. The town
may terminate service under this rider at any time upon written notice to customer. In the event that
customer violates any of the terms or conditions of this rider, or operates the generating system in a manner
which is detrimental to the town or its customers, service under this rider may be terminated immediately.
SECTIONS 15.82. – 15.85. – RESERVED.

TITLE 16. – PUBLIC WORKS: SOLID WASTE
AND RECYCLING
CHAPTER 1. – GENERAL PROVISIONS.
SECTION 16-1. – DEFINITIONS.
For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a
different meaning.
GARBAGE. Organic waste matter, both animal and vegetable, from houses, kitchens, restaurants, hotels, hospitals,
and other buildings and premises, exclusive of moisture and liquids that can be drained in a sewer, and exclusive of
excrement.
REFUSE. All garbage, rubbish, trash, debris, and waste matter, exclusive of moisture and liquids.
TRASH. All refuse exclusive of garbage and excrement.
('70 Code, § 11-1)
SECTION 16-2. – ACCUMULATION OF REFUSE PROHIBITED; DISPOSAL.
Refuse which originates upon any premises within the town shall not be suffered by the owner or occupant of the
premises to accumulate in such manner or in such quantity as to constitute a fire hazard or a danger to health, or so as
to become unsightly or otherwise give offense to persons in the neighborhood. Garbage and trash shall be disposed of
regularly, as provided in this chapter. Refuse other than garbage and trash shall be disposed of by the owner or occupant
promptly as it originates, in a sanitary and lawful manner.
('70 Code, § 11-2)
SECTION 16-3. – DISPOSAL OF CERTAIN TRASH PROHIBITED.
No person shall deposit or dispose of any garbage, trash, or refuse upon any street, sidewalk, other public place, or
vacant lot, or upon private premises owned or occupied by another, except that garbage and trash may be set out in
receptacles for collection by the town as provided in this chapter. No person shall deposit or dispose of any garbage,
trash, or refuse in any pond, lake, spring, well, or watercourse or in any gutter or drain within the town.
('70 Code, § 11-3)
SECTION 16-4. – LITTER.
(A) For the purpose of this section, LITTER shall mean paper, cartons, bottles, bottle caps, cans, fruit peelings and
pits, food, glass, scraps or fragments of any kind, and other things which have come to be regarded by the public as
litter.
(B) It shall be unlawful for any person to dispose of, or suffer to be disposed of, litter of any kind at any place within
the town except in receptacles provided for such purpose.
(C) Litter originating on any premises shall be disposed of by the owner or occupant of the premises.
(D) Litter shall not be deposited or permitted to remain upon any place where it would be subject to scattering by
children, animals, the elements of nature, or other means.
('70 Code, § 11-4)
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
392
SECTION 16-5. – REMOVING BUILDING DEBRIS; COLLECTION OF REFUSE FROM VACANT LOTS.
Building contractors, excavators, and other persons who in the course of their respective businesses cause debris or
refuse of any kind to accumulate at any place within the town shall remove and dispose of such debris or refuse
periodically before it becomes a hazard to the public health, safety, or welfare, and at the completion of each project
shall remove all such debris and refuse and dispose thereof in a sanitary and lawful manner; provided, that when debris
or refuse accumulates on any vacant lot and is not subject to removal by any contractor or other person as above
provided, the town may collect and dispose of such debris and refuse and the costs of such collection and disposal shall
become a charge against the owner of such vacant lot and shall be collectable in the same manner as taxes.
('70 Code, § 11-5)
SECTION 16-6. – FALLEN TREES, STUMPS, AND DEBRIS.
Fallen trees, stumps, and debris which are on a public right-of-way shall be collected and disposed of by the town. Fallen
trees, stumps, and debris not on a public right-of-way shall be removed promptly and disposed of in a sanitary and
lawful manner by the owners or occupants of the properties upon which they are situated.
('70 Code, § 11-6) (Ord. passed 11-2-54)
SECTION 16-7. – DISPOSAL OF CARCASSES.
(A) Property owners shall be responsible for the prompt, sanitary, and lawful disposal of animal and fowl carcasses
found upon their property, and carcasses which remain on private property for eight hours after notice to the property
owner or occupant to so dispose of any such carcass may be removed by the town at the expense of the property owner,
such expense to be collected in the same manner as property taxes. Any notice pursuant to this section which cannot
be served personally may be served by posting a copy thereof in a conspicuous place on the property whereon the
carcass is found.
(B) Animal and fowl carcasses found upon the streets or other public places shall be taken up by the office or
department of the town designated by the Town Manager and shall be disposed of in a sanitary and lawful manner.
('70 Code, § 3-6) (Ord. passed 1912; Am. Ord. 6, passed - - )
SECTION 16-8. – 16-15. – RESERVED.
CHAPTER 2. – COLLECTION SERVICE.
SECTION 16-16. – COLLECTION; NOTICE OF CHANGE IN SCHEDULING.
Garbage and trash set out for collection as provided in this chapter shall be collected by the Public Works Department
at such times as may be provided by the Director of Public Works, who shall maintain in his office at all times a current
schedule of days and routes of collection; and upon making any change in such schedule he shall give notice thereof to
the news media serving the town.
('70 Code, § 11-7)
SECTION 16-17. – RECEPTACLES FOR GARBAGE AND TRASH REQUIRED.
All householders shall provide receptacles for all garbage and trash for removal by the town. The following rules and
regulations shall be observed:
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
393
(a) Receptacles shall be made substantially of metal or plastic and provided with tight-fitting covers and strong
handles. The covers shall be kept on the receptacles at all times, except when being filled or emptied.
(b) Each receptacle shall have not more than 30-gallons capacity. If one receptacle is not sufficient to hold the
quantity of garbage or trash accumulated between collections, a sufficient number of similar receptacles shall
be provided.
(c) Business establishments may place trash in plastic containers of substantial construction, with tight-fitting
covers and strong handles. The covers shall be kept on the containers at all times, except when being filled or
emptied.
('70 Code, § 11-8)
SECTION 16-18. – BUSINESS AND COMMERCIAL ESTABLISHMENTS.
In instances where commercial receptacles are used, the owner or user thereof shall place such commercial receptacle
in a suitable location, readily accessible to the collection vehicle. Commercial establishments in the Town’ business
districts and shopping centers shall use commercial receptacles with a capacity of not more than eight (8) cubic yards
nor less than four (4) cubic yards. If the director of public works determines that it is physically impractical to locate a
commercial receptacle on the premises, he may permit garbage roll-out containers.
SECTION 16-19. – GARBAGE TO BE DRAINED OF MOISTURE AND LIQUID PRIOR TO COLLECTION.
Garbage shall be drained of liquid and moisture before being placed in a receptacle for collection by the town.
('70 Code, § 11-10)
SECTION 16-20. – CONDITIONS UNDER WHICH GARBAGE/REFUSE MAY BE REJECTED.
(a) No collector shall be required to collect garbage or trash from a defective or unsubstantial container; collect
garbage having moisture or liquid; collect garbage from a container not made of metal or plastic; collect
garbage and trash which is set out in the same container; collect any refuse which is not authorized by proper
authority of the town to be collected by the town; nor to collect any garbage or trash not set out for collection
at a location or in a manner required by this chapter or by proper authority of the town as authorized by this
chapter.
(b) Collectors who decline to remove any refuse under the provisions of this section shall notify the person who
set it out for collection by attaching thereto a notice stating the reason for rejection.
('70 Code, § 11-11)
SECTION 16-21. – TAMPERING WITH RECEPTACLES SET OUT FOR COLLECTION.
No person other than its owner or an authorized town employee or contractor shall remove the cover of any garbage
or trash receptacle which has been set out for collection, or move or tamper with any such receptacle or spill the
contents thereof.
('70 Code, § 11-12)
SECTION 16-22. – TREE LIMBS, CUTTINGS, AND SHRUBBERY.
Tree limbs, cuttings, and shrubbery of not more than one truck load may be collected by the town, upon request, when
vehicles and personnel are available, at such charge as may be specified by the Board of Commissioners, or as specified
by the Director of Public Works if at any time a schedule of such charges has not been adopted by the Board of
Commissioners. Tree limbs and the like shall be cut into lengths that can be handled easily by two men, and other matter
shall be tied in bundles or placed in secure receptacles for easy placement on the truck and so as to prevent scattering
thereof. All such matter to be collected shall be placed at the curb, readily accessible to the collection truck, but nothing
shall be placed in a gutter or other drain.
('70 Code, § 11-13)
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
394
SECTION 16-23. – LEAVES.
Leaves shall be bundled, packaged or boxed into one-man loads and placed adjacent to and behind the curb or in front
of the ditch, except during the portion of each year when special leaf collection equipment is in operation. During that
portion of each year, leaves may be piled loosely adjacent to and behind the curb or in front of the ditch for collection
by special equipment. However, such loose piles of leaves will not be collected unless they are free of trash such as
broken glass, cuttings, cans or other debris that might damage collecting equipment.
SECTION 16-24. – PROHIBITED ITEMS.
In addition to the items specified elsewhere in this article, the following items may not be placed within waste
receptacles for collection:
a) Aluminum cans;
b) Recyclable corrugated cardboard;
c) Recyclable rigid plastic containers that are required to be labeled as provided by G.S. 130-
309.10(e) that have a neck smaller than the body of the container, and that accept a screw
top, snap cap, or other closure;
d) Used oil;
e) Motor vehicle oil filters;
f) Antifreeze (ethylene glycol);
g) White goods (refrigerators, stoves and the like);
h) Lead-acid batteries;
i) Whole scrap tires, as provided in G.S. 130A-309.58(b);
j) Wooden pallets;
k) Oyster shells.
SECTION 16-25. – RESERVED FOR FUTURE USE.
SECTION 16-26. – BACKYARD COLLECTION FOR ELDERLY AND DISABLED.
Households in which no one is able to roll the roll-out container to the curb due to age or disability may qualify for
backyard garbage collection.
SECTION 16-27. – USE OF FARM PATH OR ROAD.
When three (3) or more dwellings are located on a farm path or road, the town will collect garbage and/or trash from
the front of the dwellings if the property owner enters into an agreement with the town granting the town permission
to use the farm path or road for sanitation collection purposes and further agrees that the town will in no way be
responsible or obligated for the maintenance of the farm path or road.
SECTION 16.28. – DISPOSITION OF HEAVY ACCUMULATIONS.
Building materials such as brick, broken concrete, lumber, plaster, ashes, dirt, rocks, sand or gravel, automobile frames
and parts, dead trees and other bulky, heavy material shall be disposed of by the owner or person controlling same,
according to applicable regulations.
SECTION 16-29. – OCCUPANT RESPONSIBLE FOR TRASH ALLOWED TO ACCUMULATE.
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
395
Garbage and trash allowed to accumulate beyond such time of collection or any garbage or trash ordered removed by
the health department shall be the responsibility of the resident, establishment or industry to haul and dispose of same
as directed by the health department or director of public works.
SECTION 16-30. – MULTIPLE HOUSING UNITS.
Multi-family residential housing units and mobile home parks with five (5) units or more are required to use commercial
receptacles.
SECTION 16-31. – NONRESIDENT USE OF COLLECTION SERVICES.
It shall be unlawful for any person not a resident of the town to deposit or cause to be deposited for collection by the
town any garbage or trash in any container within the town if such garbage or trash is brought into the town for the
purpose of such disposition.
SECTION 16-32. – PERMIT FOR CUTTING OR TRIMMING TREES; REMOVAL OF CUT OR TRIMMED
MATERIALS.
It shall be unlawful for any person(s) to cut or trim trees for compensation within the town without a privilege
license. Such person or contractor shall be responsible for removing trimmed limbs, trash and stump.
(Ord. 05-11, passed 5-3-05)
SECTION 16-33. – SPECIAL SERVICES (AS MANPOWER AND EQUIPMENT AVAILABLE; WRITTEN
APPLICATION WITH RIGHT-OF-ENTRY REQUIRED.
(a) Dump truck for debris removal provided for individuals, nonprofits and churches upon request to Public Works
Director. A truck will be placed on the property for loading of large amounts of debris by the individual or
group. This service may be made available two times per week, no more than four times per year at no cost. An
equipment charge will be billed for amounts in excess of the above described use.
(b) On-site pickup of yard and bulk debris available for individual homeowner, when unable to place yard and bulk
debris at curbside for pickup or where said bulk waste may obstruct sidewalk or street. The material shall be
piled and accessible where no hand or manual cleanup is necessary. A fee for said service shall be charged
based on the towns schedule for equipment rental.
(c) Contractor is required to remove shingles, roofing materials and/or other building material generated by
contractor’s work, where compensation is received for services rendered. Any roofing material or shingles
placed for pickup by individual or business where owner performed work shall be billed at equipment rate, plus
landfill fees.
(d) Tires placed out for pickup by the town by an individual shall be collected by the Sanitation Department. A
report of said collection will be forwarded to the finance office and cost of disposal will be charged to the
individual’s account. Tires with rims will not be picked up unless the rims are removed.
(e) Yard waste or white goods shall be placed on the property of the person or individual who generates such
waste. Said location shall be at the front property line. Said yard waste and white goods shall not be placed
so that it interferes with drainage or street sweeping.
(Ord. 05-11, passed 5-3-05)
SECTIONS 16-34. – 16-40. –RESERVED.
CHAPTER 3. – RECYCLING.
SECTION 16-41. – RECYCLING; COLLECTION OF RECYCLED MATERIALS.
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
396
The Town strongly encourages recycling efforts. Recycling containers (one per dwelling) are provided by the town at no
charge and remain the property of the town. Additional or replacement containers will be provided by the town upon
payment of a fee established by the town. Recycling containers shall be stored and placed for collection in accordance
with the same requirements applicable to garbage containers. Only those materials that are acceptable for recycling
shall be placed within the recycling containers. Recyclable items include: Plastic drink bottles and milk jugs; clear, brown
and green glass food or beverage containers; aluminum cans; newspapers bundled, not tied, on top of the container
(wet newspapers are acceptable); used motor oil, placed in a clear plastic jug with a secure fitting lid and placed beside
the recycling bin; and, recyclable corrugated cardboard. The public works department shall provide adequate public
notice from time to time of the types of solid wastes that may be placed within these recycling containers for collection
by the town.
SECTION 16-42. – 16-45. – RESERVED.
CHAPTER 4. – SOLID WASTE FEES.
SECTION 16-46. – SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT FEE.
The Town of Red Springs shall provide for the collection and disposal of garbage and trash in accordance with the
requirements and standards set forth in this Title. A solid waste management fee shall be charged to all residents of the
town and all businesses and commercial establishments of the town. The fee (or fees) shall be in an amount to be
determined from time to time by the Board of Commissioners and listed in the schedule of fees and charges maintained
in the Clerk's office.
SECTIONS 16-47. – 16-50. – RESERVED.
CHAPTER 5. – PRIVATE HAULERS.PREVENTION AND ABATEMENT OF PUBLIC NUISANCES
SECTION 16-51. – ROBESON COUNTY FLOW CONTROL.
Effective 4 March 2014, the Town of Red Springs adopted the Robeson County Solid Waste Management Ordinance
#20120506 concerning flow control of solid waste in the county. This ordinance provides that all garbage collected
within the Town of Red Springs is to be disposed of at a designated Robeson County facility. No private haulers may
contract to remove waste from locations within the Town of Red Springs to any location outside the control of Robeson
County.
(Resolution adopted March 4, 2014.)
