397
TITLE 17. – STREETS AND SIDEWALKS
CHAPTER 1. - GENERAL
SECTION 17.1. – DAMAGE TO STREETS OR SIDEWALKS; RECOVERY OF COSTS TO REPAIR.
No person shall injure, deface or mar in any manner whatsoever any of the streets or sidewalks of the town. The town
shall have the right and privilege to repair any such injury, defacement or mar and assess the cost thereof against the
offender.
SECTION 17.2. – GRADES.
The town shall have the authority to establish and change the grades of the streets and sidewalks within the town as
may be necessary.
SECTION 17.3. – GRADE LEVEL OF RAILROAD TRACKS.
a) It shall be unlawful for any railroad company to lay down tracks in or on any street or avenue in the
town without having first obtained from the town the proper grade of such street or avenue over
which the line of such railroad is to run if such street or avenue has been brought to grade. Such
railroad shall be put on exact grade so as not to impede or interfere with travel. If such street or
avenue has not been brought to grade, then such railroad must be laid so as to conform to the then
surface of the street so as not to interfere with travel over and along such street. If any company shall
lay down tracks on streets not brought to grade, the right of the town to grade such street in the
future shall not be prejudiced, and the owners, proprietors and lessees of such railroad tracks shall be
required to raise or lower such tracks so as to conform to the grade of the streets, without cost to the
town, whenever the Board of Commissioners may direct the same to be done.
b) Nothing in this section shall be so construed as to prejudice the existing rights of the town to compel
all persons or companies now owning or controlling railroad tracks in the town to raise or lower the
tracks so as to conform to grade of streets when such streets are brought to grade.
SECTION 17.4. – OBSTRUCTION OF STREETS OR SIDEWALKS.
a) No persons shall obstruct any of the streets or sidewalks in the town in such manner as to hinder or
delay the travel thereon on foot or otherwise. For purposes of this section, the term "obstruct" means
to place a physical barrier or object within such street or sidewalk. In such case it shall be the duty of
the police to cause such obstruction removed and to keep such streets and sidewalks clear for the
travel of the public.
b) No person shall obstruct any of the streets or sidewalks in the town by placing thereon any boxes,
merchandise or other things. This section shall not be construed to prevent merchants from making
reasonable use of sidewalks when receiving or shipping goods, nor shall it prevent the use of three (3)
feet of sidewalk space next to their stores for the display of goods, provided that no such display shall
be made unless the entire sidewalk area is paved from the building or property line to the curb line
and +unless ample space is left on sidewalk for pedestrians.
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
398
c) This section shall not be construed so as to prohibit the town to barricade, rope off or otherwise
obstruct any street or sidewalk in the town when the same may become necessary for the protection,
health or welfare of the citizens of the town.
State Law Reference— Town's duty to keep public streets free from unnecessary obstructions, G.S. § 160A-296(a)(2).
SECTION 17.5. – PROTECTION OF STREETS OR SIDEWALKS UNDER CONSTRUCTION.
No person shall ride, lead or drive or cause to be ridden, led or driven, any horse or other animal or drive or cause to be
driven any automobile or other vehicle upon any street or sidewalk when the same is barricaded and under the process
of construction, nor shall any person in any other manner cause any damage to such street or sidewalk.
SECTION 17.6. – VEHICLES ON SIDEWALKS.
No person shall ride, pull, push or drive any vehicle whatsoever, except baby carriages, on any of the sidewalks within
the fire limits.
State Law Reference— Driving motor vehicle on sidewalk prohibited, G.S. § 20-160.
SECTION 17.7. – CERTAIN WHEELS, TIRES, ETC. RESTRICTED.
It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or cause to be driven any traction engine or other vehicle with lugs or
corrugations in the wheels thereof over the permanently paved streets of the town, unless suitable provisions are made
by planking or otherwise to the satisfaction of the town so that such corrugations or lugs will not damage the pavement.
SECTION 17.8. – DEPOSIT OF GLASS OR OTHER SHARP OBJECTS ON STREETS.
No person shall throw, place or deposit any glass or other sharp cutting substance or any injurious obstruction in or
upon any of the public streets of the town.
State Law Reference— Placing glass or injurious obstruction upon highway prohibited, G.S. § 136-91.
SECTION 17.9. – AWNING DIMENSIONS.
It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or maintain any awning or other similar object which has a clearance of less
than seven (7) feet above the level of any sidewalk or which extends over the traveled portion of the street in front of
the building to which it may be attached; provided, however, that stationary awning arms shall be at least eight (8) feet
above the level of the sidewalk.
SECTION 17.10. – DAMAGE TO CURBS.
It shall be unlawful for any person to break and remove the street curbing in any of the town's improved streets, except
when a permit for the same has been issued by the town.
State Law Reference— Authority to regulate digging in the streets, G.S. § 160A-296(6); curb cut regulations, G.S. § 160A-
307.
SECTION 17.11. – STREET NUMBERS FOR BUILDINGS.
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
399
a) All structures fronting on any street or alley in the town shall be numbered in some conspicuous place,
by the owner thereof, according to the map made by the town for such purpose and on file in his
office, all odd numbers being on one (1) side of the street and all even numbers on the other.
b) Any person desiring to have a number put on his structure shall first apply to the town for the proper
number, and any person failing or refusing to put the proper number on his structure or putting the
wrong number thereon or failing or refusing to comply with any other requirement of this section shall
be guilty of a misdemeanor.
SECTION 17.12. – BARBED WIRE PROHIBITED.
No person shall erect, maintain or allow on any premises along any street or alley of the town any barbed wire or barbed
wire fence where or in such manner as to constitute a danger to passers-by.
SECTION 17.13. – WHEN ELECTRIC FENCES ALLOWED.
It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, install or construct, operate or maintain or allow the installation or operation
of a fence or similar structure or device which is electrically charged within the corporate limits without obtaining a
permit from the building inspector and enclosing such electric fence, structure or device with a fence at least four (4)
feet in height and of sufficient density to restrain anyone from coming in contact with such electric fence, structure or
device and posting a warning sign.
SECTIONS 17.14. – 17.25 – RESERVED.
CHAPTER 2. – LOCAL IMPROVEMENTS.
SECTION 17.26. – AUTHORITY OF BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS.
The provisions of this article shall not make it mandatory upon the Board of Commissioners to approve any petitions for
local improvements, nor shall the Board of Commissioners be obligated in any manner to cause any local improvements
to be made pursuant to any petitions that may be approved, and all improvements made or authorized by the Board of
Commissioners shall be subject to the availability of funds.
SECTION 17.27. – PROCEDURES AND METHODS.
The procedures and methods of making public improvements as provided for in this article shall be governed by and be
in accordance with the provisions of the General Statutes and the Charter, as amended, as the same shall apply to the
town.
SECTION 17.28. – ASSESSMENTS FOR IMPROVEMENTS - GENERAL.
Except as otherwise provided in this article, all local improvements within the town of the nature set forth in this article
shall be made by assessment against the abutting property owners in accordance with the provisions of the General
Statutes and the Charter, as amended, as the same shall apply to the town, and the cost of such improvements shall be
apportioned as provided in this article. However, in any project for any of the improvements or combination thereof
within the town of the nature set forth in this article in which the total cost to be paid by the town for the project will
not be more than the total cost to be paid by the town on an assessment basis as set forth in the General Statutes, the
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
400
Charter, as amended, and this article and in the project for any such improvements in which all or a portion of the costs
thereof are paid from community development block grant funds provided by the federal government, the Board of
Commissioners may, in its discretion, elect to perform the project without assessing abutting property owners for any
portion of the cost thereof.
SECTION 17.29. – ASSESSMENTS FOR IMPROVEMENTS - STREETS.
Assessments for street surfacing or resurfacing improvements, except for street intersections, shall be by assessment
of one-third of the total cost against the abutting property owners on each side of the street being improved; the
remaining one-third and the cost of improving street intersections shall be paid by the town. The total cost subject to
assessment shall include engineering costs, excavation, sub-base, base course paving and any other costs which may be
involved and shall also include all costs involved in street drainage, piping, catch basins, manholes and associated
structures wherever located, except on private property. To the sum of all costs assessed against each property owner,
eight (8) percent of that cost will be added to cover legal and assessment costs.
SECTION 17.30. – ASSESSMENTS FOR IMPROVEMENTS – CURBS AND GUTTERS.
Assessments for curb and gutter improvements shall be made by assessing against the abutting property owner onehalf
of the total cost per lineal foot of curb and gutter for each foot of the property owner's frontage, with the town to
pay one-half of the cost. The cost of curb and gutter shall include engineering, grading and any other costs involved in
the curb and gutter portion of the street improvement involved.
SECTION 17.31. – EFFECT OF PRIOR ASSESSMENTS.
No assessment shall be made against an abutting property owner for street improvements for which an assessment has
previously been made.
SECTION 17.32. – CERTAIN IMPROVEMENTS AT COST OF TOWN.
Street surfacing or resurfacing improvements, including curbs and gutters, at street intersections, exclusive of sidewalks
at such intersections, will be paid by the town. The town will share in the cost of oversized street improvements as
provided by Section 17-36.
SECTION 17.33. – MAINTENANCE WORK NOT TO BE ASSESSED.
a) Resurfacing of streets which have previously been improved (i) where the costs of such improvements
were paid by assessment as provided by state law, the town Charter and this article, or (ii) the total
cost of such improvements paid by the town was not more than the town would have paid on an
assessment basis, or (iii) such improvements as constructed comply with the right-of-way and design
and construction standards shall be considered maintenance and shall be done and performed at the
expense of the town without assessment against the abutting property owners.
b) All other surfaced streets classified as local access residential streets shall be maintained in such
street's existing condition by patch maintenance until such street has been improved on an
assessment basis as provided in this article or has been improved with curb and gutter without
assessment at a total cost to the town of not more than the town would have paid on an assessment
basis as provided in this article.
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
401
SECTION 17.34. – PROVISION FOR SIDEWALK IMPROVEMENTS WITHOUT ASSESSMENT; PROTECTING
THE PUBLIC WELFARE.
If the Board of Commissioners shall, in its discretion, determine that heavy pedestrian traffic exists and likely will
continue to exist for an indefinite period along any street within the town and that such pedestrian traffic is generated
by facilities operated and maintained by public funds such as a public school and that the convenience, safety and
welfare of the public generally would be served and promoted by the construction and maintenance of sidewalks on
either or both sides of such street, the Board of Commissioners may cause sidewalks to be constructed on either or both
sides of such street without expense to the property owners abutting on such sidewalks.
SECTION 17.35. – CORNER LOT EXEMPTION.
If a corner lot is used as a single lot, where surfacing and other associated street improvements have already been made
on an assessment basis on the intersecting street on which the lot abuts, no assessment shall be made against the lot
for improvement on the non-improved side for any part of the frontage of such lot, except that portion in excess of one
hundred fifty (150) feet or seventy-five (75) percent of the improved frontage, whichever is greater. This section shall
only apply to residential lots.
SECTION 17.36. – IMPROVEMENTS TO OVERSIZED STREETS.
When a street is to be improved on an assessment basis and it is necessary for the street to be wider than a local access
street (thirty-one (31) feet back of curb to back of curb), the abutting property owners shall only be assessed for those
improvement costs which would have been assessed if the street had been a local access street, with the remainder of
the additional cost being borne by the town. When a street is to be improved on an assessment basis and it is necessary
or desirable to use street drainage pipes with a diameter in excess of fifteen (15) inches, the abutting property owners
shall only be assessed for the cost of fifteen-inch drainage pipe, with the additional cost of a pipe in excess of fifteen
(15) inches in diameter being borne by the town.
SECTIONS 17.37. – 17.50. – RESERVED.
CHAPTER 3. – DRIVEWAYS.
SECTION 17.51. – APPLICABILITY.
Except as otherwise expressly provided, the provisions of this article shall apply and shall govern the construction of all
driveways, whether for commercial purposes or establishments or noncommercial purposes or establishments, within
the town.
SECTION 17.52. – PROCEDURE FOR DRIVEWAY IMPROVEMENTS.
Before any driveway shall be constructed, built or repaired within the town, the person desiring to do the same shall:
a) Obtain a zoning permit from the Town;
b) Obtain an appropriate permit from the building inspector;
c) Pay a permit fee in an amount to be determined from time to time by the Board and listed in the schedule of
fees and charges maintained in the Clerk's office.
SECTION 17.53. – NUMBER AND WIDTH OF DRIVES.
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
402
No individual driveway entrance constructed within the town shall be of a greater width than fifty (50) feet, measured
parallel to the street or roadway, or wider than one-third of the lot frontage, whichever is smaller. If the lot frontage
does not permit the use of two (2) driveways of one-third lot frontage as limited in this section, then one (1) combined
entrance and exit of a maximum width of fifty (50) feet may be provided. Notwithstanding the above and regardless of
the number of driveways, the combined width of all driveways shall not exceed two-thirds of the width of the lot on any
street.
SECTION 17.54. – AREA BETWEEN AND ADJACENT TO DRIVEWAYS.
The frontage on the street or road right-of-way other than the driveway itself shall be both curb and gutter or in the
form of a ditch or drain. Modification thereof may be permitted, provided proper drainage is constructed and curbs or
posts or other safeguards are installed to prevent misuse. A written permit for any modification must be obtained from
the town before any work is started.
SECTION 17.55. – RETURN RADII.
Suitable return radii for driveways shall be provided as determined by the building inspector.
SECTION 17.56. – CORNER SIGHT AREAS.
At intersections where sight-distance or clear-vision areas have been obtained, no driveway shall be permitted to cross
such areas. The driveway at the right-of-way line should begin at a point no closer than the intersection of the sightdistance
line and the right-of-way line.
SECTION 17.57. – DRAINAGE.
The drainage in street or roadside ditches shall not be altered or impeded. The person constructing any driveway within
the town shall provide suitable drainage structures at entrances and exits at his own expense.
SECTION 17.58. – INTERSECTIONS.
No driveway or entrance shall be permitted to enter directly into an intersection, but shall be so placed as to turn traffic
into a major or minor street before passing through the intersection.
SECTION 17.59. – PROPERTY LINE OFFSET – COMMERCIAL DRIVEWAYS.
All commercial driveways shall be so located that the flared portion thereof adjacent to the travelled way will not
encroach on adjacent property. A minimum distance of five (5) feet shall be reserved between the driveway and the
property line.
SECTION 17.60. – PROPERTY LINE OFFSET – NON-COMMERCIAL DRIVEWAYS.
All noncommercial driveways shall be so located that the flared portion thereof adjacent to a traveled way shall not
encroach on adjacent property. A minimum distance of eighteen (18) inches shall be reserved between the driveway
and the property line.
SECTION 17.61. –COMMERCIAL DRIVEWAY ENTRANCES AND EXITS.
For all commercial driveways, curbs, channelizing islands or posts shall be so constructed or placed as to define
entrances and exits to the degree needed to prevent entire frontages from being used as driveways and thereby
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
403
eliminating parking immediately adjacent to the travelled way and in front of business places. Between each driveway,
if there is more than one (1), there shall be a channelizing island between the property line and the street curb for a
minimum length parallel with the street of eight (8) feet along the property line and such greater length along the curb.
SECTION 17.62. – ANGLE OF COMMERCIAL DRIVEWAYS.
The angle of commercial driveways shall not be less than forty-five (45) degrees with the edge of the street or roadway,
except that on dual streets or roadways where there is a median strip, the entrance angle may be decreased to not less
than thirty (30) degrees. Exit drives onto dual streets or roadways shall have an angle of not less than sixty (60) degrees
with the edge of the street or roadway.
SECTION 17.63. – SLOPE OF COMMERCIAL DRIVEWAYS.
The grade of entrance and exit of commercial driveways shall slope away from the street or road surface at a rate of not
less than one-fourth inch per foot and not more than one (1) inch per foot for the distance between the sidewalk and
the street or roadway, unless the grade of the sidewalk requires a variance there from.
SECTIONS 17.64. – 19.70. – RESERVED.
CHAPTER 4. – CONTROL OF VEGETATION AT INTERSECTIONS.
SECTION 17.71. – DEFINITIONS.
For the purpose of this article, "street gutter flow line" means the street gutter flow line of the curb adjacent to and
bordering upon each such restricted area. If there is no such curb, the height restrictions set forth in this article shall be
based upon the actual level of the paved or used portion of the public street adjacent to and bordering upon each such
restricted area.
SECTION 17.72. – ENFORCEMENT.
In addition to any penalty which may be imposed for the violation of this article, the town shall have the power, subject
to constitutional limitations, to enter upon and remove from the triangular corner areas described in this article any of
the growths prohibited by this article. The town shall not be liable to the owners of such property for such entry and
removal.
SECTION 17.73. – RESTRICTED AREAS.
a) The areas in the town restricted by the provisions of this article are as follows:
1) All of that portion of land lying within a triangular shaped area on each street corner within
the town described by metes and bounds as follows:
Beginning at the precise corner of intersection point of the curbs of each of the two (2) streets
forming each corner and extending twenty (20) feet along each such curb line from the curb
intersection point, the third side being determined by the drawing of a straight line from the
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
404
ends of such twenty-foot extensions, whether the land is privately owned or unpaved or
untraveled street right-of-way property.
2) Where no curbs are in existence at such street intersections, the twenty-foot lines shall
coincide with the central flow line of the ditches paralleling such uncurbed streets as shall be
determined by the town.
b) However, the provisions of this article shall apply only to those areas of the town designated and
classified by the town's zoning ordinance requiring construction on lots in zoned sections to be set back
from the property line of each such lot.
SECTION 17.74. – MAXIMUM HEIGHT OF GROWTH.
No person shall plant, grow or maintain in any restricted area described in this article any plant, hedge, shrub or other
growth, except trees, at a height greater than three (3) feet from the street gutter flow line.
SECTION 17.75. – MINIMUM CLEARANCE OF TREES.
Any trees planted, grown and maintained in any restricted area described in this article shall not have branches or foliage
extending from the trunk thereof at a height lower than ten (10) feet from the street gutter flow line.
SECTIONS 17.76. – 17.80 – RESERVED.
CHAPTER 5. – STREET NAMES AND NUMBERING.
SECTION 17.81. – STREET NAMES AND PROPERTY NUMBERING MAP; ASSIGNMENT.
That certain map, which is and shall remain on file in the office of the Town Clerk, and which is entitled "The Street
Naming and Property Numbering System of the Town of Red Springs, North Carolina," and dated May, 1960, is hereby
adopted as the official street naming and property numbering map of the town. All street names and property numbers
assigned shall be in accordance with this map. No other street names or property numbers shall be used or displayed
in the town, except names and numbers assigned in accordance with the official map.
('70 Code, § 16-16; 2009 Supp) (Ord. passed 5-3-60)
SECTION 17.82. – NUMBER SYSTEM DESCRIBED.
On the map adopted by Section 17.81. there shall be designated a north-south axis and an east-west axis, and all
avenues, streets, or alleys running generally north and south shall be numbered from the east-west axis consecutively
to the town limits or to the extremity of such avenue, street, or alley. Avenues, streets, or alleys running generally east
and west shall be numbered from the north-south axis in the same manner. Where there are minor exceptions to this,
the map as adopted shall govern. One hundred numbers shall be allowed to each block so that the number of each
consecutive block shall commence with consecutive hundreds and one.
('70 Code, § 16-17, 2009 Supp)
One whole number shall be assigned for every 50 feet of ground, whether improved property or vacant lot, on each
street within the town, except in the area designated by the Board of Commissioners as the business area, in which one
whole number for each 25 feet of ground, whether improved or not, shall be assigned. Odd numbers shall be assigned
to the left side of the street and even numbers to the right side going from the axis toward the town limits.
('70 Code, § 16-18, 2009 Supp) (Ord. passed 5-3-60
SECTION 17.83. – INSTALLATION AND DISPLAY OF NUMBERS.
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
405
Owners of residences, business buildings, and other improved property shall install and maintain thereon the numbers
assigned thereto in accordance with the map adopted, and all residences and business buildings erected hereafter shall
be assigned a number in accordance with that map. Numbers shall be displayed in a conspicuous place on the property
to which they appertain, so as to be easily read from the street line, and they shall be of aluminum metal or other type
approved by the Board of Commissioners.
('70 Code, § 16-19) (Ord. passed 2-2-60; Am. Ord. passed 5-3-60)
SECTION 17.84. – ALTERING, DEFACING OR REMOVING NUMBERS.
It shall be unlawful for any person to alter, deface, or take down any number placed on any property in accordance
with this subchapter, except for repair or replacement of such number.
('70 Code, § 16-20) (Ord. passed 5-3-60)

TITLE 18. – VEHICLES FOR HIRE
CHAPTER 1. - GENERAL
SECTION 18-1. – 18-10. – RESERVED
CHAPTER 2. – TAXICABS, LIMOUSINES AND OTHER VEHICLES FOR HIRE
SECTION 18-11. - DEFINITIONS
As used in this division, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them:
Certificate shall mean a certificate of convenience and necessity granted to the owner of a taxicab business by
the Board of Commissioners for each taxicab operated by him in the town.
Driver shall mean any person physically in charge of or driving a taxicab.
Owner shall mean any person having control of the operation or maintenance and collection of the revenue of
taxicabs.
Permit shall mean a permit granted by the town to the driver of a taxicab.
Street shall mean any street, alley, avenue, lane, public place or highway within the town.
Taxicab shall mean any vehicle for hire for the purpose of transporting passengers upon the streets, except
vehicles operating over a fixed route and between fixed termini.
SECTION 18-12. – OPERATORS AND DRIVERS DISTINGUISHED
a) "To operate one or more taxicabs" shall mean to engage in the taxicab business with such taxicabs in
the town by causing taxicabs which are under a person's ownership or control to be propelled, either
by himself or by someone under his direction or supervision, for the purpose of carrying passengers
for hire. An operator is a person who operates one or more taxicabs.
b) "To drive a taxicab" shall mean to be physically in control of a taxicab whether or not such taxicab be in motion,
when such taxicab is being used for, or is available or ready to be used for, the carrying of passengers for hire.
A driver is one who drives a taxicab. The same person may or may not be both an operator and a driver.
SECTION 18-13. – VEHICLE FOR HIRE INSPECTOR.
a)` There is hereby created the office of vehicle for hire inspector (referred to in this article as the
"inspector"). The inspector shall be appointed by the Board of Commissioners and shall enforce the
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
408
provisions of this article and shall fulfill all duties required under this article, including the inspection
of any vehicle for hire and the issuance of all driving permits.
b) The inspector shall advise the Board of Commissioners with regard to matters covered or incidentally
involved in the operation or administration of this article. He shall make recommendations with
respect to the adequacy of service and whether or not there are too many or too few vehicles to serve
the public's convenience or necessity, and he shall make such other reports and furnish such other
information to the city Board as may be requested from the city Board from time to time.
State Law Reference— Power f town to regulate, etc. drivers and operators of vehicles for hire, G.S. § 20-37 and G.S. §
160A-304; authority to levy tax on taxicabs, G.S. § 20-97; Financial responsibility of taxicab operators, G.S. § 20-280.
SECTION 18-14. –INFORMATION TO BE FILED BY OWNER/OPERATORS.
Every owner shall file with the inspector the owner's name, business address, home address, if applicable, business and
home telephone numbers and a list showing the serial number and make of all vehicles for hire owned and operated by
the owner and names, license numbers and addresses of all drivers working for the owner, and, within three days after
any change in connection with such information, the owner shall report such change to the inspector. If the owner is a
partnership or a limited liability company, the names, business addresses, home addresses and home telephone
numbers shall be given for each of the partners or members thereof.
SECTION 18-15. – ADDITIONAL PASSENGERS.
No taxicab driver shall permit any other person to occupy or ride in the taxicab, unless the person or persons first
employing the taxicab shall consent to the acceptance of additional passenger or passengers.
SECTION 18-16. – MAXIMUM SEATING.
It shall be unlawful to carry in a taxicab more than five (5) passengers in any taxicab, and in no event shall more than
two (2) passengers ride in the front seat with the driver.
SECTION 18-17. – RECEIPT, DISCHARGE OF PASSENGERS.
No driver of a taxicab shall receive or discharge passengers in the roadway of any street, but shall drive to the righthand
sidewalk, as nearly as possible, or, in the absence of a sidewalk, to the extreme right-hand side of the road, and
there receive or discharge passengers.
SECTION 18-18. – ACTING ON BEHALF OF PROSTITUES AND UNLAWFUL ESTABLISHMENTS.
It shall be unlawful for any taxicab driver or owner to act in any manner as a panderer or pimp for prostitutes or as
contact for unlawful establishments of any character, or to knowingly transport any passenger to the abode of a
prostitute.
SECTION 18-19. – ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES – TRANSPORTATION PROHIBITED.
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
409
It shall be unlawful to transport alcoholic beverages, not owned and in the exclusive possession and control of a farepaying
passenger, in the taxicab or for any taxicab driver to have on his person any alcoholic beverages while driving
and operating a taxicab in service.
SECTION 18-20. – ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES- CONSUMPTION IN VEHICLE.
It shall be unlawful for any driver or passenger of any taxicab to drink alcoholic beverages of any kind while inside the
taxicab.
SECTION 18-21. – ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES – SALE.
No driver of a taxicab or owner of a taxicab shall engage in selling intoxicating liquors or soliciting business for any person
selling intoxicating liquors.
SECTION 18-22. – DISPLAY OF RATES.
There shall be posted in each taxicab at a conspicuous place a copy of the rates for the hiring of the taxicab.
SECTION 18-23. – ENGAGING TAXI SERVICE WITH THE INTENT TO DEFRAUD.
It shall be unlawful for any person to fraudulently engage of use any taxicab not intending at the time to pay for the use
of the taxicab and then refuse to pay the regular rates charged by the operators.
SECTION 18-24. – CERTIFICATE OF CONVENIENCE AND NECESSITY REQUIRED.
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a taxicab upon and over the streets of the town without first having applied
for and secured from the Board of Commissioners a certificate of convenience and necessity for each vehicle operated.
State Law Reference— Requirement of certificate of public convenience and necessity, G.S. 20-87; State license for
taxicab not to issue unless town has issued certificate of public convenience and necessity, G.S. § 20-87(c). Authority to
grant taxicab franchises and to limit number of cabs in operation, G.S. 160A-304.
SECTION 18-25. – APPLICATION FOR CERTIFICATE OF CONVENIENCE AND NECESSITY.
Each person desiring to operate a taxicab upon and over the streets of the town shall file on forms supplied by the town
Clerk an application for a certificate of convenience and necessity.
SECTION 18-26. – SCHEDULE FOR HEARING APPLICATIONS.
Each application for a certificate of convenience and necessity shall be scheduled for a hearing at the next regularly
scheduled meeting of the Board of Commissioners; provided, such application shall be filed with the town Clerk at least
ten (10) days prior to such regularly scheduled meeting, otherwise, the hearing will be held at such time as the Board of
Commissioners shall determine.
SECTION 18-27. – LIABILITY INSURANCE.
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
410
a) Each applicant for a certificate required by this division shall first furnish, and shall thereafter keep in
force and effect, for each such vehicle operated by him under this article, a policy of liability insurance,
providing liability insurance in the amount specified by state law. Such liability insurance shall be
provided by a company authorized and licensed to do business in the state and at least having a
process agent in the state.
b) Compliance with subsection (a) insurance is declared to be a condition precedent to the operation of
any of the taxicabs upon the public streets of the town.
State Law Reference— Proof of financial responsibility as requisite to obtaining any certificate of convenience and
necessity, G.S. § 20-280.
SECTION 18-28. – FACTORS FOR DETERMINATION OF CONVENIENCE AND NECESSITY.
a) In determining whether the public convenience and necessity requires the franchising of a taxicab, the Board
of Commissioners shall, among other things, take into consideration the following factors:
1. The financial responsibility of the applicant and the likelihood of the proposed service being
permanent, responsible and satisfactory.
2. The number and condition of equipment.
3. The number of taxicabs now operated and the demand for increased service, if any, and whether or
not the safe use of streets by the public, both vehicular and pedestrian, will be preserved, and whether
or not adequate provision has been made for off-street parking of such taxicabs.
4. The experience of applicant in the taxicab business.
5. Such other relative facts as may be deemed necessary and advisable. Before making any decision with
respect to the issuance of a certificate of convenience and necessity, the Board of Commissioners shall
make a full and complete investigation of all facts, and may, if it so desires, subpoena witnesses and
utilize the service of the chief of police or any other officer or employee of the town.
6. The burden of proof shall be upon the applicant to establish the existence of public convenience and
necessity for the operation of the taxicab specified in his application, and all other facts required for
the granting of a certificate.
SECTION 18-29. - ISSUANCE OR DENIAL.
The Board of Commissioners shall have power and it shall be its duty to order certain certificates issued, to refuse to
issue certain certificates or to issue certificates for a partial exercise only of the privileges sought. The Board of
Commissioners may attach to the exercise of the rights granted by such certificates such terms and conditions as in its
judgment the public convenience and necessity may require.
SECTION 18-30. – FAILURE TO BEGIN OPERATIONS WITHIN 60 DAYS.
If a certificate is granted to an applicant and the applicant shall fail, in accordance with the provisions of the certificate,
to begin operations within sixty (60) days after the date of such certificate, then the certificate shall become null and
void.
SECTION 18-31. – TRANSFER.
A certificate of convenience and necessity is not transferable without the consent of the Board of Commissioners.
Application for a permit to transfer shall be filed in the same manner as an application for a certificate of convenience
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
411
and necessity. The proceedings upon such application for a transfer shall be the same as those described for the issuance
of a certificate.
SECTION 18-32. - REVOCATION.
The Board of Commissioners may, at any time after a public hearing, revoke any certificate issued by authority of this
division for any one (1) or more of the following causes:
a) Failure to operate the taxicab specified in the certificate in such manner as to serve the public adequately and
efficiently.
b) Failure to maintain motor equipment in good repair.
c) Failure to carry liability insurance.
d) Failure to pay to the town taxes or license fees imposed upon taxicabs.
e) Repeated and persistent violation by the taxicab drivers of traffic and safety ordinances.
f) Violation of state laws relating to alcoholic beverages or prostitution.
g) Failure to report accidents.
h) Willful failure to comply with any provision of this chapter or other provisions of this Code or other town
ordinances or state laws relating to the operation of taxicabs.
i) Violating ordinances fixing fares or failure to post cab fares charged.
j) Possession of any intoxicating liquors as defined by the laws of this state by any taxicab driver while in the
operation of any taxicab owned by the holder of a certificate of convenience and necessity.
SECTION 18-33. - DUE PROCESS FOR REVOCATION.
No certificate shall be revoked until the owner has had at least five (5) days' notice by personal service or registered
mail of the charges against him, and of the time and place of the hearing. If, after the hearing, it is found that the owner
is guilty of one or more of the offenses listed herein, the Board of Commissioners shall have the power to revoke the
certificate, or to condition a revocation upon compliance of its order within any time fixed by it.
SECTION 18-34. – SUBSTITUTION OF VEHICLES.
Any person to whom a certificate of convenience and necessity has been issued may, by appropriate endorsement
thereon by the town manager, substitute other vehicles for the vehicles for which certificates were granted. In such
instance, the liability insurance or bonds shall also be transferred to such substitute vehicles.
SECTION 18-35. – REGULARITY OF OPERATION.
Each person having complied with the provisions of this chapter and obtained a certificate of convenience and necessity
to operate a taxicab shall be required to operate the taxicab in his business with reasonable regularity. The certificate
of convenience and necessity of each taxicab operator shall be subject to revocation if the operator fails to operate the
taxicab for any period of sixty (60) days. Each operator of a taxicab who fails to operate it over any period of sixty (60)
days shall be given ten (10) days' notice to appear before the Board of Commissioners to show cause why his certificate
of convenience and necessity should not be revoked. If, upon such hearing, it shall appear that the taxicab is not being
operated in the interest of the convenience and necessity of the public and not being operated with reasonable
regularity, the Board of Commissioners is authorized to revoke the certificate of convenience and necessity.
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
412
SECTION 18-36. – CRIMINAL HISTORY OF APPLICANTS.
The police department and its full-time employees are authorized to access the DCI/SBI Criminal History Record
Information to check the state repository for the criminal history of all applicants for certificates of necessity and
convenience and taxi driver permits.
Applicants for these certificates and permits will be rejected if they have been convicted of any felony or any
misdemeanor involving the use, sale or possession of a controlled substance or fraud.
SECTION 18-37. – DRIVER ’S PERMITS REQUIRED.
It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any vehicle for hire within the city, or within a distance of five miles thereof,
without first having obtained a vehicle for hire driver's permit as provided in this division.
State Law Reference— Power of city as to permits, G.S. 20-37, 160A-304.
SECTION 18-38. – APPLICATION.
An application for a vehicle for hire driver's permit shall be made upon blanks furnished by the city for such purpose
and shall state, among other things, the name, address, physical condition, physical description, former employers,
present or prospective employer, court record and state chauffeur's license number.
SECTION 18-39. – QUALIFICATIONS.
No person shall be eligible to receive a vehicle for hire driver's permit, as provided in this division, nor shall a certificate
holder permit any person to drive a vehicle for hire under this division unless such person possesses the following
minimum qualifications:
(1) Mental and physical condition.
a. Drivers shall have no mental, nervous, organic or functional disease likely to interfere with safe driving.
b. Drivers shall have no loss or impairment of the use of the foot, leg, fingers, hand or arm, or other structural
defect or limitation likely to interfere with safe driving.
(2) Eyesight. The eyesight of the drivers shall comply with the following requirements:
a. Visual activity shall be at least 20/40 (Snellen) in each eye, with or without glasses or corrective lens;
b. Form field of vision in the horizontal meridian shall be at least a total of 140 degrees; and
c. The ability to distinguish between the colors red, green and yellow.
Drivers requiring correction by glasses or corrective lens shall use prescribed eye wear at all times when operating a
vehicle for hire.
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
413
(3) Hearing. Hearing of drivers shall not be less than 10/10 in the better ear, for conversational tones, with or
without a hearing aid. Drivers requiring aids shall wear the aids, in proper operating condition, at all times when
driving.
(4) Liquor, narcotics and drugs. Drivers shall not be addicted to the use of narcotics or habit-forming drugs, or the
excessive use of alcoholic beverages or liquors.
SECTION 18-40. – PROOF OF MEETING PHYSICAL AND MENTAL REQUIREMENTS.
Prior to the issuance or renewal of any driver's permit, the inspector may, in his sole discretion, require the applicant to
furnish written medical proof that the driver meets the physical and mental requirements of this code. Such written
proof shall be transmitted by the doctor to the inspector and kept on file in the inspector's office.
SECTION 18-41. – INVESTIGATION OF THE APPLICANT.
The inspector shall investigate the applicant for a vehicle for hire driver's permit in any way he sees fit and in order to
confirm the facts stated in the application filed as provided in this code. If the inspector shall find that such applicant is
of good moral character, sound physical and mental condition, and without infirmities which might render him unfit for
the safe operation of a vehicle, and such applicant is a citizen of the United States and is not a habitual violator of the
traffic laws, then, unless such applicant shall be ineligible by reason of the further provisions of this division, the
inspector shall issue the driver's permit.
SECTION 18-42. – REFUSAL TO APPROVE APPLICATIONS.
(a) If the applicant for a vehicle for hire driver's permit, as required by this division, shall have been convicted
two times of the crime of manslaughter by a motor vehicle; two times of assault with a motor vehicle;
three times of speeding; two times of reckless driving; two times of violation of any law regulating or
prohibiting the possession, sale or use of alcoholic liquors, narcotics or drugs or three times of aiding and
abetting in the violation of any such laws; or two times of violation of any of the provisions of G.S. 14-204
in regard to prostitution and assignation, then the inspector shall refuse to approve the application.
(b) If such applicant shall have been convicted of speeding or aiding in the violation of any law regulating or
prohibiting the possession, sale or use of alcoholic liquors, narcotics or drugs within the six-month period
immediately preceding the date of his application or shall have been convicted for the second time of
speeding or aiding in the violation of any law regulating or prohibiting the possession, sale or use of
alcoholic liquors, narcotics or drugs within the two-year period immediately preceding the application,
then the inspector shall refuse to approve the application.
(c) If such applicant shall have been convicted of speeding or aiding in the violation of any law regulating or
prohibiting the possession, sale or use of alcoholic liquors, narcotics or drugs within the six-month period
immediately preceding the date of his application or shall have been convicted for the second time of
speeding or aiding in the violation of any law regulating or prohibiting the possession, sale or use of
alcoholic liquors, narcotics or drugs within the two-year period immediately preceding the application,
then the inspector shall refuse to approve the application.
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
414
(d) If such applicant shall have been convicted for the third time within the two-year period immediately
preceding the date of his application of violation of any traffic laws or regulations other than as specifically
named in this section, then the inspector shall refuse to approve the application.
SECTION 18-43. – FEES.
(a) Except as otherwise provided, the applicant for a vehicle for hire driver's permit, as required by this division,
shall pay to the town the currently required amount for such permit, which sum shall accompany the
application. Such permit fee shall be for a permit to drive a vehicle for hire for the remainder of the fiscal year
during which the driver's permit was issued. If no permit is issued to the applicant because of a reason as set
forth in this division, the permit fee shall be retained by the city to defray the expense of the investigation of
the applicant.
(b) If a vehicle for hire driver's permit issued under this division is suspended or revoked for any cause as provided
in this division or if the person to whom the vehicle for hire driver's permit is issued voluntarily turns in such
permit to the vehicle for hire inspector before the expiration of such permit, there shall be no refund of the fee
paid for the driver's permit.
(c) If a driver allows his permit to expire by not renewing the permit on an annual basis, and he later applies for
another driver's permit, the application shall be treated as a new application and the driver shall pay to the city
treasurer the currently required amount as provided in subsection (a) of this section.
(d) Upon the annual renewal of a vehicle for hire driver's permit, the payment of the current renewal fee shall be
required.
SECTION 18-44. – ISSUANCE.
Upon the inspector's approval of an application for a vehicle for hire driver's permit, filed as provided in this division,
the inspector shall issue, pursuant to this division and upon the payment of the required fees, a vehicle for hire driver's
permit pursuant to the approved application.
SECTION 18-45. – DISPLAY.
At all times while driving or in charge of a vehicle for hire, each driver shall prominently display in such vehicle the
vehicle for hire driver's permit issued under this division to such driver, so as to be easily visible to the passengers in
such vehicle.
SECTION 18-46. – DESIGNATION OF OWNER FOR WHOM PERMIT HOLDER TO DRIVE.
A vehicle for hire driver's permit issued under this division shall specify the owner for whom the holder of the permit is
to drive. No driver shall drive a vehicle for hire for any owner other than the owner designated in the vehicle for hire
driver's permit issued to such driver without procuring a new permit from the inspector designating such new owner.
SECTION 18-47. – REVOCATION AND SUSPENSION.
(a)At any time after the issuance of a vehicle for hire driver's permit to any person, the inspector shall revoke or suspend
the permit if the permittee shall be convicted of any of the following offenses, and such permit shall be revoked or
suspended for the period set forth for each offense in the following table:

(b) At any time after the issuance of a vehicle for hire driver's permit to any person under this division, such

of this division or for any other causes which may be set out in the provisions of this Code or other ordinance
of the city.
SECTION 18-48. – RENEWAL.
The holder of a vehicle for hire driver's permit issued under this division shall renew such permit annually on or before
July 1.
SECTION 18-49. – RESPONSIBILITY OF THE OWNER OF VEHICLE FOR HIRE.
Town of Red Springs CODE OF ORDINANCES 2015 Revision
416
The owner of the vehicle for hire shall be responsible to make sure all drivers working for him shall have valid driver's
permits, and it shall be the duty of the owner to report to the inspector any violation of the regulations set forth in this
division and, further, to report to the inspector any change in the mental and/or physical condition of any driver.
SECTIONS 18-50. – 18-60 – RESERVED.
